title: Advanced Features and Customization
text: make_cld() function provides several parameters customizing output behavior.

title: Advanced Features and Customization
text: default, letters assigned ‚Äú‚Äù representing group lowest mean/median. can reverse :
code: result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE)  # Default ordering make_cld(result) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__  # Reversed ordering make_cld(result, reversed = TRUE) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   c        __c #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  ab        ab_ #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   a        a__ #>  sunflower   c        __c

title: Advanced Features and Customization
text: Sometimes order group names comparisons needs swapped:
code: # Swap the order of compared groups make_cld(result, swap_compared_names = TRUE)

title: Advanced Features and Customization
text: debugging understanding comparison process:
code: # Print comparison names during processing make_cld(result, print_comp = TRUE)

title: Advanced Features and Customization
text: Control comparison strings processed:
code: # Remove spaces from comparison strings make_cld(df, remove_space = TRUE)  # Replace colons with hyphens make_cld(df, swap_colon = TRUE)  # Remove equal signs make_cld(df, remove_equal = TRUE)  # Replace "vs" with hyphens make_cld(df, swap_vs = TRUE)

title: Supported Input Formats
text: make_cld() function works seamlessly multiple input formats, making versatile tool creating compact letter displays various statistical packages custom data.

title: Supported Input Formats
code: # Pairwise Wilcoxon rank sum test result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) make_cld(result) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__

title: Supported Input Formats
code: # Pairwise t-test result2 <- pairwise.t.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed) make_cld(result2, alpha = 0.01)  # More stringent threshold #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.01  #> Method:  t tests with pooled SD  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__

title: Supported Input Formats
text: can use symmetric matrices p-values directly:
code: # Create a symmetric matrix of p-values m <- matrix(c(   1.00, 0.22, 0.05, 0.00,   0.22, 1.00, 0.17, 0.01,   0.05, 0.17, 1.00, 0.22,   0.00, 0.01, 0.22, 1.00 ), nrow = 4) rownames(m) <- colnames(m) <- c("GroupA", "GroupB", "GroupC", "GroupD")  # Generate CLD make_cld(m, alpha = 0.05) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  matrix  #>  #>   group cld spaced_cld #>  GroupA   a         a_ #>  GroupB   a         a_ #>  GroupC  ab         ab #>  GroupD   b         _b

title: Supported Input Formats
text: package supports results PMCMRplus non-parametric post-hoc tests:
code: library(PMCMRplus)  # Kruskal-Wallis post-hoc test kw_result <- kwAllPairsConoverTest(count ~ spray, data = InsectSprays) make_cld(kw_result)  # Dunn test dunn_result <- kwAllPairsDunnTest(count ~ spray, data = InsectSprays) make_cld(dunn_result)

title: Supported Input Formats
text: rstatix package provides tidyverse-compatible statistical tests. Since rstatix returns data frames, need specify column names groups p-values:
code: library(rstatix)  # Games-Howell test (for unequal variances) gh_result <- games_howell_test(PlantGrowth, weight ~ group) make_cld(gh_result, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p.adj")  # Tukey HSD test tukey_result <- tukey_hsd(PlantGrowth, weight ~ group) make_cld(tukey_result, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p.adj")  # Pairwise t-test pwt_result <- pairwise_t_test(PlantGrowth, weight ~ group) make_cld(pwt_result, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p.adj")

title: Supported Input Formats
text: DescTools package offers various post-hoc tests:
code: library(DescTools)  # Conover test conover_result <- ConoverTest(count ~ spray, data = InsectSprays) make_cld(conover_result)  # Dunnett test (comparison to control) dunnett_result <- DunnettTest(weight ~ group, data = PlantGrowth) make_cld(dunnett_result)

title: Supported Input Formats
text: can create CLDs custom comparison results stored data frames:
code: # Custom comparison results comparisons <- data.frame(   group1 = c("Treatment_A", "Treatment_A", "Treatment_B"),   group2 = c("Treatment_B", "Treatment_C", "Treatment_C"),   p.adj  = c(0.9, 0.02, 0.03) )  make_cld(comparisons, alpha = 0.05) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  data.frame  #>  #>        group cld spaced_cld #>  Treatment_B   a         a_ #>  Treatment_C   b         _b #>  Treatment_A   a         a_

title: Supported Input Formats
text: data frame uses different column names, specify :
code: # Data frame with custom column names my_comparisons <- data.frame(   first_group = c("A", "A", "B"),   second_group = c("B", "C", "C"),   adjusted_p = c(0.9, 0.02, 0.03) )  make_cld(my_comparisons,   gr1_col = "first_group",   gr2_col = "second_group",   p_val_col = "adjusted_p",   alpha = 0.05 ) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  data.frame  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      B   a         a_ #>      C   b         _b #>      A   a         a_

title: Supported Input Formats
text: formula interface provides convenient way specify p-values comparison labels. two formula formats available:

title: Supported Input Formats
text: hyphens allowed group names using format used separators.
code: # Using formula for data frames with comparison strings my_data <- data.frame(   Comparison = c("A-B", "A-C", "B-C"),   p_value = c(0.12, 0.001, 0.045),   p_adjusted = c(0.18, 0.003, 0.068) )  # Use the adjusted p-values make_cld(p_adjusted ~ Comparison, data = my_data) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  formula  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a         a_ #>      B  ab         ab #>      C   b         _b  # Or use the raw p-values make_cld(p_value ~ Comparison, data = my_data) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  formula  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a         a_ #>      B   a         a_ #>      C   b         _b

what: Two-variable formula (recommended for group names with hyphens)
title: Supported Input Formats
text: group names contain hyphens special characters, use two-variable formula format specifies groups separately:
code: # Data with group names containing hyphens my_data2 <- data.frame(   group1 = c("Treatment-A", "Treatment-A", "Treatment-B"),   group2 = c("Treatment-B", "Treatment-C", "Treatment-C"),   p_adjusted = c(0.18, 0.003, 0.068) )  # Two-variable formula (handles hyphens automatically) make_cld(p_adjusted ~ group1 + group2, data = my_data2)

what: What is a Compact Letter Display?
title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: Compact Letter Display (CLD) visualizes multiple pairwise comparison results compact format assigning letters groups: Groups sharing least one letter significantly different Groups shared letters significantly different convention widely used agricultural research, biology, statistics present post-hoc test results.

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: Interpretation: casein () sunflower () share letter ‚Äú‚Äù linseed (bc) meatmeal (ac) share letter ‚Äúc‚Äù horsebean (b) linseed (bc) share letter ‚Äúb‚Äù horsebean (b) soybean (c) share letters horsebean (b) sunflower () share letters casein () horsebean (b) share letters
code: # Example with shared letters result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) cld_result <- make_cld(result) cld_result #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: Pattern 1: different (, b, c) ‚Üí groups significantly different Pattern 2: One different (, , b) ‚Üí first two groups different Pattern 3: Overlapping (, ab, bc, c) ‚Üí creates chain non-significant differences
code: set.seed(123) data1 <- data.frame(   value = c(rnorm(10, 10, 1), rnorm(10, 20, 1), rnorm(10, 30, 1)),   group = rep(c("Low", "Medium", "High"), each = 10) ) make_cld(pairwise.t.test(data1$value, data1$group)) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  t tests with pooled SD  #>  #>   group cld spaced_cld #>    High   a        a__ #>     Low   b        _b_ #>  Medium   c        __c set.seed(455) data2 <- data.frame(   value = c(rnorm(10, 10, 1.5), rnorm(10, 10.1, 1.5), rnorm(10, 20, 1.5)),   group = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10) ) make_cld(pairwise.t.test(data2$value, data2$group)) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  t tests with pooled SD  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a         a_ #>      B   a         a_ #>      C   b         _b set.seed(889) data3 <- data.frame(   value = c(rnorm(10, 10, 3), rnorm(10, 13, 3), rnorm(10, 16, 3), rnorm(10, 19, 3)),   group = rep(c("G1", "G2", "G3", "G4"), each = 10) ) make_cld(pairwise.t.test(data3$value, data3$group)) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  t tests with pooled SD  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>     G1   a        a__ #>     G2  ab        ab_ #>     G3  bc        _bc #>     G4   c        __c

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: spaced_cld column aligns letters vertically using underscores (_) spaces, making patterns easier visualize monospaced fonts.

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: Lower alpha values conservative, resulting fewer significant differences:
code: result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) make_cld(result, alpha = 0.05)   # Standard #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__ make_cld(result, alpha = 0.01)   # Stringent #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.01  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein  ab        ab_ #>  horsebean   c        __c #>    linseed  ac        a_c #>   meatmeal  ab        ab_ #>    soybean  ab        ab_ #>  sunflower   b        _b_ make_cld(result, alpha = 0.001)  # Very stringent #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.001  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a          a #>  horsebean   a          a #>    linseed   a          a #>   meatmeal   a          a #>    soybean   a          a #>  sunflower   a          a

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: P-value adjustment methods (Bonferroni, Holm, FDR, etc.) control Type error inflation can significantly impact results. Use p.adjust.method argument pairwise test function.

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
text: ‚ùå Wrong: ‚ÄúGroup ‚Äò‚Äô higher values group ‚Äòb‚Äô‚Äù ‚úÖ Correct: Letters indicate grouping, magnitude rank. show groups differ statistically. üí° Tip: Sort groups original means/medians understand groups higher lower values.

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays
code: result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) cld_result <- make_cld(result)  # Access stored information attr(cld_result, "alpha")           # Significance level #> [1] 0.05 attr(cld_result, "method")          # Statistical method #> [1] "Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction" attr(cld_result, "n_comparisons")   # Total comparisons #> [1] 15 attr(cld_result, "n_significant")   # Significant comparisons #> [1] 8

title: Understanding and Interpreting Compact Letter Displays

title: Getting Started with cld
text: cld package provides easy consistent way create compact letter displays (CLDs) visualizing results pairwise statistical comparisons. Groups sharing letter significantly different ‚Äî convention widely used agricultural, biological, statistical publications.

title: Getting Started with cld
text: ‚úÖ Universal compatibility - Works outputs base R, PMCMRplus, rstatix, DescTools, custom data frames ‚úÖ Consistent interface - One function (make_cld()) handles input types ‚úÖ Publication-ready - Generate clean, professional statistical grouping labels ‚úÖ Well-tested - 250+ tests ensuring reliability across methods ‚úÖ Informative output - Stores metadata (alpha, method, comparison counts) transparency

title: Getting Started with cld
text: cld package works various statistical test outputs. ‚Äôs simple example: Interpretation: Groups sharing least one letter significantly different (e.g., casein sunflower ‚Äú‚Äù); Groups shared letters significantly different (e.g., horsebean ‚Äúb‚Äù soybean ‚Äúc‚Äù).
code: # Run a pairwise test test_result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE)  # Generate compact letter display make_cld(test_result) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__

title: Getting Started with cld
text: make_cld() function returns cld_object (enhanced data frame) : Columns: group - Names groups compared cld - Compact letter display (letters ) spaced_cld - Monospaced version alignment (underscores replace spaces) Attributes (metadata): alpha - Significance level used method - Statistical test/method name n_comparisons - Total number pairwise comparisons n_significant - Number significant differences found
code: result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) cld_result <- make_cld(result)  # View result cld_result #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__  # Access metadata attributes(cld_result)[c("alpha", "method", "n_comparisons", "n_significant")] #> $alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $method #> [1] "Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction" #>  #> $n_comparisons #> [1] 15 #>  #> $n_significant #> [1] 8

title: Getting Started with cld
code: # Extract as named character vector letters_only <- as.character(cld_result) letters_only #>    casein horsebean   linseed  meatmeal   soybean sunflower  #>       "a"       "b"      "bc"      "ac"       "c"       "a"  # Convert back to plain data frame (removes metadata) plain_df <- as.data.frame(cld_result) class(plain_df) #> [1] "data.frame"

title: Getting Started with cld
code: result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE)  # Standard (alpha = 0.05) make_cld(result, alpha = 0.05) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__  # More stringent (alpha = 0.01) make_cld(result, alpha = 0.01) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.01  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein  ab        ab_ #>  horsebean   c        __c #>    linseed  ac        a_c #>   meatmeal  ab        ab_ #>    soybean  ab        ab_ #>  sunflower   b        _b_

title: Getting Started with cld
text: ‚ùå least one shared letter ‚Üí Groups significantly different ‚úÖ shared letters ‚Üí Groups significantly different Examples: ‚ùå Groups ‚Äúc‚Äù ‚Äúc‚Äù share letter ‚Äúc‚Äù ‚Üí difference significant ‚ùå Groups ‚Äú‚Äù ‚Äúab‚Äù share letter ‚Äú‚Äù ‚Üí difference significant ‚ùå Groups ‚Äúab‚Äù ‚Äúbc‚Äù share letter ‚Äúb‚Äù ‚Üí difference significant ‚ùå Groups ‚Äúabc‚Äù ‚Äúbcd‚Äù share letters ‚Äúb‚Äù, ‚Äúc‚Äù ‚Üí difference significant ‚úÖ Groups ‚Äú‚Äù ‚Äúc‚Äù share letters ‚Üí significantly different ‚úÖ Groups ‚Äúabd‚Äù ‚Äúce‚Äù share letters ‚Üí significantly different

what: Compact Letter Display for Post-Hoc Comparisons
title: Compact Letter Display for Post-Hoc Comparisons
text: Simplify statistical reporting compact letter displays cld package provides easy consistent way create compact letter displays (CLDs) visualizing results pairwise statistical comparisons. Groups sharing letter significantly different ‚Äî convention widely used agricultural, biological, statistical publications.

title: Compact Letter Display for Post-Hoc Comparisons
text: Key Features: üîÑ Universal compatibility - Works base R, PMCMRplus, rstatix, DescTools, custom formats üéØ One function - make_cld() handles input types automatically üìä Publication-ready - Clean, professional statistical grouping labels üìù Informative - Stores metadata (alpha, method, comparison counts) üõ†Ô∏è Well-tested - Comprehensive unit tests ensure reliability

title: Compact Letter Display for Post-Hoc Comparisons
text: cld package works various statistical test outputs. ‚Äôs simple example: Interpretation: Groups sharing least one letter significantly different (e.g., casein sunflower ‚Äú‚Äù); Groups shared letters significantly different (e.g., horsebean ‚Äúb‚Äù soybean ‚Äúc‚Äù).
code: library(cld)  # Run a pairwise test test_result <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE)  # Generate compact letter display make_cld(test_result) #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
text: Generic function convert various objects cld_object format. useful CLD results packages custom formats want use cld's methods.

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
code: as_cld(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' as_cld(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'character' as_cld(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'cld_object' as_cld(x, ...)

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
text: x Object convert cld_object ... Additional arguments passed methods

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
text: cld_object (data frame class c("cld_object", "data.frame")) containing three columns: group - Character. names groups cld - Character. compact letter display group spaced_cld - Character. monospaced version CLD spaces replaced underscores, useful maintaining alignment output

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
text: as_cld() function provides way convert various formats standard cld_object structure. particularly useful : Working CLD results packages Converting custom formats use cld's print coercion methods Creating CLD objects programmatically

title: Convert objects to cld_object ‚Äî as_cld
code: # Convert from data frame df <- data.frame(   group = c("A", "B", "C"),   cld = c("a", "b", "b") ) as_cld(df) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a          a #>      B   b          b #>      C   b          b  # Convert from named character vector letters_vec <- c(A = "a", B = "b", C = "b") as_cld(letters_vec) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a          a #>      B   b          b #>      C   b          b

title: Print and coercion methods for cld_object ‚Äî cld_methods
text: print.cld_object(): Invisibly returns input object .data.frame.cld_object(): Returns plain data frame .character.cld_object(): Returns named character vector letters as_tibble.cld_object(): Returns tibble

title: Print and coercion methods for cld_object ‚Äî cld_methods
code: obj <- pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) result <- make_cld(obj)  # Print method print(result) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__  # Convert to plain data frame as.data.frame(result) #>       group cld spaced_cld #> 1    casein   a        a__ #> 2 horsebean   b        _b_ #> 3   linseed  bc        _bc #> 4  meatmeal  ac        a_c #> 5   soybean   c        __c #> 6 sunflower   a        a__  # Convert to named character vector as.character(result) #>    casein horsebean   linseed  meatmeal   soybean sunflower  #>       "a"       "b"      "bc"      "ac"       "c"       "a"   # Convert to tibble if (requireNamespace("tibble", quietly = TRUE)) {   tibble::as_tibble(result) } #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 #>   group     cld   spaced_cld #>   <chr>     <chr> <chr>      #> 1 casein    a     a__        #> 2 horsebean b     _b_        #> 3 linseed   bc    _bc        #> 4 meatmeal  ac    a_c        #> 5 soybean   c     __c        #> 6 sunflower a     a__

what: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
text: Creates compact letter display results pair-wise comparisons (e.g., ANOVA post-hoc tests, Kruskal-Wallis post-hoc tests, others). Groups share letter significantly different . provides visual summary groups differ significantly, commonly used agricultural, biological, statistical reporting.

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
code: make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'pairwise.htest' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'PMCMR' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'PostHocTest' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'DunnTest' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'formula' make_cld(obj, ..., data = NULL, alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'matrix' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' make_cld(   obj,   ...,   alpha = 0.05,   gr1_col = "group1",   gr2_col = "group2",   p_val_col = "p.adj",   remove_space = FALSE )  # S3 method for class 'pairwise_pval_df' make_cld(obj, ..., alpha = 0.05)

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
text: obj Object pair-wise comparisons (e.g., post-hoc test results). Currently supported object classes: PMCMR - packages PMCMR PMCMRplus pairwise.htest - base R (e.g., pairwise.t.test, pairwise.wilcox.test) data.frame - comparison results packages like rstatix (e.g., games_howell_test, tukey_hsd). Requires gr1_col, gr2_col, p_val_col specification. PostHocTest - package DescTools (e.g., ConoverTest, DunnettTest) DunnTest - package DescTools matrix - symmetric matrices p-values formula - interface data frames pairwise_pval_df - output pval_matrix_to_df() ... arguments passed internal methods. may include: reversed - Logical. TRUE, reverses letter ordering (default: FALSE) swap_compared_names - Logical. TRUE, swaps group order comparisons (default: FALSE) print_comp - Logical. TRUE, prints comparison names (default: FALSE) sep - Character. Custom separator comparison strings (default: "-"). Use group names contain hyphens. example, use sep = ":" sep = ";". applies single-variable formula method. needed two-variable formula. Additional cleaning options (default: TRUE methods): remove_space - Removes spaces comparison strings remove_equal - Removes equal signs comparison strings swap_colon - Replaces colons hyphens (use FALSE using : separator) swap_vs - Replaces "vs" hyphens (default: FALSE) alpha Numeric value 0 1. significance level (alpha) determining comparisons significantly different. Comparisons p-values threshold considered significant. Default 0.05. data data frame p-values names comparisons. argument required obj formula. data frame contain least two columns: one p-values one comparison labels. See examples details. gr1_col Character string. Name column data frame containing first group names pairwise comparison. Default "group1". used data.frame method. function construct comparisons format gr2-gr1. gr2_col Character string. Name column data frame containing second group names pairwise comparison. Default "group2". used data.frame method. p_val_col Character string. Name column data frame containing p-values comparison. Default "p.adj" (adjusted p-values). used data.frame method. Can also "p_value" column name containing numeric p-values. remove_space Logical. TRUE, removes spaces comparison strings. Default FALSE data.frame method preserve original formatting. Set TRUE group names contain spaces want compact comparisons. formula R model stats::formula() two possible formats: Two-variable formula (recommended): p_value ~ group1 + group2 group1 group2 separate columns containing group names. format automatically handles hyphens group names. Single-variable formula: p_value ~ Comparison Comparison column pre-formatted comparison strings (e.g., "-B", "-C"). format limitations hyphenated group names. Usually used combination data.

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
text: data frame class c("cld_object", "data.frame") three columns: group - Character. names groups compared cld - Character. compact letter display group. Groups sharing least one letter significantly different spaced_cld - Character. monospaced version CLD spaces replaced underscores, useful maintaining alignment output rows ordered according group names. Groups letter(s) differ significantly specified alpha level.

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
text: underlying multcompView package uses hyphens (-) default separator group names comparison strings (e.g., "GroupA-GroupB"). creates conflict group names contain hyphens (e.g., "Plant-based", "Treatment-1"). Automatic Handling: methods (matrix, data.frame, pairwise.htest, pairwise_pval_df, others) automatically detect handle hyphens group names : Temporarily replacing hyphens alternative characters (underscore, en-dash, etc.) Processing comparisons Restoring original hyphens output informational message shown occurs. suppress , use quiet_hyphen_warning = TRUE. Formula Method Limitation: formula method (e.g., make_cld(p_value ~ comparison, data = df)) limited support group names hyphens receives pre-formatted comparison strings separator hyphens reliably distinguished hyphens within group names. Best Practice Hyphenated Group Names: Use data.frame method gr1_col gr2_col parameters. method handles hyphens automatically seamlessly. example:   Alternative Workarounds Formula Method: Convert data matrix format (also handles hyphens automatically) Replace hyphens group names underscores creating comparisons Use different separator comparison strings (e.g., " vs " swap_vs = TRUE)
code: # Instead of: make_cld(p_value ~ comparison, data = df) # Use: make_cld(df, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p_value")

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
text: Piepho HP (2004). algorithm letter-based representation -pairwise comparisons. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 13(2), 456-466. doi:10.1198/1061860043515 , available https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1198/1061860043515

title: Make a compact letter display (CLD) for pair-wise comparisons ‚Äî make_cld
code: # Example 1: Using pairwise.htest (Wilcoxon test) obj1 <- stats::pairwise.wilcox.test(chickwts$weight, chickwts$feed, exact = FALSE) cld::make_cld(obj1) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction  #>  #>      group cld spaced_cld #>     casein   a        a__ #>  horsebean   b        _b_ #>    linseed  bc        _bc #>   meatmeal  ac        a_c #>    soybean   c        __c #>  sunflower   a        a__  # Example 2: Using pairwise.htest (t-test) obj2 <- with(OrchardSprays, stats::pairwise.t.test(decrease, treatment)) cld::make_cld(obj2) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  t tests with pooled SD  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a        a__ #>      B   a        a__ #>      C   a        a__ #>      D  ab        ab_ #>      E  bc        _bc #>      F   c        __c #>      G   c        __c #>      H   c        __c  # Example 3: Using pairwise.htest (proportion test) # \donttest{ smokers <- c(83, 90, 129, 70) patients <- c(86, 93, 136, 82) obj3 <- stats::pairwise.prop.test(smokers, patients) #> Warning: Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect #> Warning: Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect #> Warning: Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect cld::make_cld(obj3) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Pairwise comparison of proportions  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      1   a          a #>      2   a          a #>      3   a          a #>      4   a          a # }  # Example 4: Using PMCMR objects # \donttest{ obj4 <- PMCMRplus::kwAllPairsConoverTest(count ~ spray, data = InsectSprays) #> Warning: Ties are present. Quantiles were corrected for ties. cld::make_cld(obj4) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  Conover's all-pairs test  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      A   a        a__ #>      B   a        a__ #>      C   b        _b_ #>      D   c        __c #>      E  bc        _bc #>      F   a        a__ # }  # Example 5: Using DescTools objects # \donttest{ obj5 <- DescTools::ConoverTest(weight ~ group, data = PlantGrowth) cld::make_cld(obj5) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  ConoverTest  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>   trt1   a         a_ #>   trt2   b         _b #>   ctrl  ab         ab # }  # Example 6: Using rstatix data frames (via data.frame method) # \donttest{ obj6 <- rstatix::games_howell_test(PlantGrowth, weight ~ group) cld::make_cld(obj6, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p.adj") #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  data.frame  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>   trt1   a         a_ #>   trt2   b         _b #>   ctrl  ab         ab # }  # Example 7: Using formula interface my_dataframe <- utils::read.table(   text = c(     'Comparison     p_value p.adjust     "EE - GB = 0"        1 1.000000     "EE - CY = 0" 0.001093 0.003279     "GB - CY = 0" 0.005477 0.008216'   ),   header = TRUE ) cld::make_cld(p.adjust ~ Comparison, data = my_dataframe) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  formula  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>     EE   a         a_ #>     GB   a         a_ #>    GB0  ab         ab #>    CY0   b         _b  # Example 8: Using a symmetric matrix of p-values # Create matrix m <- c(   1.00, 0.22, 0.05, 0.00,   0.22, 1.00, 0.17, 0.01,   0.05, 0.17, 1.00, 0.22,   0.00, 0.01, 0.22, 1.00 ) obj8 <- matrix(m, nrow = 4) rownames(obj8) <- colnames(obj8) <- c("P", "O", "I", "U") obj8 #>      P    O    I    U #> P 1.00 0.22 0.05 0.00 #> O 0.22 1.00 0.17 0.01 #> I 0.05 0.17 1.00 0.22 #> U 0.00 0.01 0.22 1.00  # Make CLD cld::make_cld(obj8) #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  matrix  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      P   a         a_ #>      O   a         a_ #>      I  ab         ab #>      U   b         _b  # Example 9: Using data.frame method with custom column names my_data <- data.frame(   group1 = c("A", "A", "B"),   group2 = c("B", "C", "C"),   p.adj = c(0.001, 0.045, 0.892) ) cld::make_cld(my_data, gr1_col = "group1", gr2_col = "group2", p_val_col = "p.adj") #> Compact Letter Display (CLD) #> Signif. level (alpha):  0.05  #> Method:  data.frame  #>  #>  group cld spaced_cld #>      B   a         a_ #>      C   a         a_ #>      A   b         _b

what: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
title: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
text: function converts matrix p-values data frame three columns: gr1 (column names), gr2 (row names), p_values (p-values). particularly useful symmetric matrix p-values pairwise comparisons need convert long-format data frame analysis use make_cld().

title: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
code: pval_matrix_to_df(x)

title: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
text: x numeric matrix containing p-values. matrix column row names, assigned sequential numbers. matrix can symmetric (diagonal upper/lower triangle) triangular. NA values removed output.

title: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
text: data frame class c("pairwise_pval_df", "data.frame") columns: gr1 - names columns matrix gr2 - names rows matrix p_values - corresponding p-values matrix (excluding NA values)

title: Convert matrix with p-values to data frame ‚Äî pval_matrix_to_df
code: # Create a matrix of p-values m <- matrix(c(NA, 0.05, 0.01, 0.05, NA, 0.03, 0.01, 0.03, NA), nrow = 3) colnames(m) <- c("A", "B", "C") rownames(m) <- c("A", "B", "C")  # Convert to data frame cld::pval_matrix_to_df(m) #>   gr1 gr2 p_values #> 2   A   B     0.05 #> 3   A   C     0.01 #> 4   B   A     0.05 #> 6   B   C     0.03 #> 7   C   A     0.01 #> 8   C   B     0.03
